I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) from the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) will promote responsible and sustainable financing in the People’s Republic of China (PRC) 
and support regional cooperation and integration (RCI) in the financial sector. It will (i) help 
financial sector regulators and institutions in the PRC adopt international best practices in 
responsible and sustainable finance; (ii) develop innovative financial sector products in areas 
such as blue financing,1 disaster risk financing, longevity financing, inclusive financing, and digital 
financing;  and  (iii)  support  regional  learning  and  knowledge  sharing  on  responsible  and 
sustainable financing, especially through the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), 
including the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS), and the Central Asia Regional Economic 
Cooperation (CAREC) program platforms.2 These efforts are expected to generate regional public 
goods (RPGs) through the delivery of environmental and social benefits, as well as promote RCI 
in financial sector development in Asia and the Pacific.3  
 
2.  In tandem with the operational priorities of the current PRC Country Partnership Strategy 
(CPS), 2016-2020 and ADB’s Strategy 2030 for supporting the PRC’s high-quality growth and 
green development, the ADB is expanding its support for building climate change resilience, 
fostering environmental sustainability, and tackling emerging social issues (such as elderly care) 
in the country.4 To achieve the CPS and Strategy 2030’s objectives, the PRC’s financial sector 
needs to become more effective and innovative in addressing environmental and climate change 
challenges, including fostering green economic recovery and development post coronavirus 
disease (COVID-19) pandemic. This includes the adoption of international best practices in the 
PRC, particularly in making its financing activities responsible and sustainable. Promoting RPGs 
and strengthening financial sector cooperation both feature prominently in ADB’s Strategy 2030 
operational priority of supporting RCI. The TA will expand the concepts, practices, and benefits 
of responsible and sustainable financing through the ASEAN+3 financial cooperation platforms, 
including GMS countries, while also promoting knowledge sharing with the CAREC countries 
(paras. 6–9). The TA is on the list that ADB and the government agreed upon on 22 January 2020.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  After four decades of rapid economic growth, the PRC has become an upper middle-
income country, but at a cost of substantial environmental damage and rising inequality. The 
PRC’s 13th Five-Year Plan for 2016–2020 calls on the financial sector to play a larger role in 
helping the country transition to a green, high-quality growth trajectory.5 This transition is expected 
to continue under the forthcoming 14th Five-Year Plan for 2021–2025. However, the financial 
sector remains undeveloped in key aspects of responsible and sustainable financing, especially 
in the adoption of important concepts and standards developed globally in recent years. These 
 
1  Blue finance refers to the support to the sustainable use of marine resources while preserving the health of ocean 
ecosystem. Reducing the land-based pollution to the ocean is a key area.  
2  ASEAN includes 11 Southeast Asian countries. ASEAN+3 add the PRC, Japan, and Republic of Korea. GMS 
includes 5 Southeast Asian countries and the PRC along the Mekong River. CAREC includes 11 Central West Asian 
countries and the PRC. 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of the ADB website on 11 September 2020. The title of 
the TA was revised to better reflect the scope of the TA. 
4  ADB. 2016. Transforming Partnership: People’s Republic of China and Asian Development Bank, 2016–2020. Manila;

5  National Development and Reform Commission. 2016. 13th Five-Year Plan (2016–2020). Beijing. ADB. 2016.

2 
include the Principles for Responsible Investments (PRI),6 the Equator Principles;7 environment, 
social, and governance (ESG) analysis; and the sustainability disclosure standards of the Global 
Reporting Initiative (GRI).8 As of 2020, only seven commercial banks in the PRC have issued a 
total of 36 ESG-related products, and only five commercial banks have adopted the Equator 
Principles. GRI requirements for banks and capital markets are yet to be introduced and adopted.  
 
4.  In particular most regional based financial institutions, such as city and rural commercial 
banks and other small financial institutions, are unaware of these international best practices. 
They also lack the capacity to implement innovative financing products needed to advance the 
country’s environment and social development agenda. Likewise, adopting some responsible and 
sustainable financing practices, such as the Equator Principles, is still on a voluntary basis, and 
there have been few benchmarks. Therefore, introducing, formalizing, and expanding responsible 
and sustainable financing best practices is imperative.  
 
5.  Because  the  PRC  has  the  second-largest  economy  in  the  world,  an  expansion  in 
responsible and sustainable financing can materially improve regional environmental conditions, 
which will generate significant RPGs. The PRC will gain valuable knowledge and practical 
experiences through its responsible and sustainable financing development process. Sharing 
such knowledge and experiences in the region, particularly in promoting international best 
practices, will expand learning and green finance development across countries and support 
financial sector RCI. Through these regional platforms, ADB will also leverage the TA resources 
to promote (i) green and sustainable business development opportunities, (ii) the transfer of 
sustainable and green technologies, and (iii) project-level trade and investment opportunities such 
as  linking  PRC  investment  to  regional  green  projects.  These  are  to  be  achieved  through 
mechanisms such as (i) the ASEAN+3 financial cooperation platforms of the Asian Bond Markets 
Initiative (ABMI), including the Credit Guarantee and Investment Facility (CGIF), the ASEAN+3 
Bond Market Forum, and the ASEAN Capital Markets Forum (ACMF); and (ii) the CAREC platform. 
The resulting improved asset quality (e.g., by reducing the project environmental and social 
compliance risk) and the development of more sustainable asset class (e.g., from green and blue 
bonds) with alternative risk-return structure will bring in concrete benefits to capital markets 
development and more sustainable infrastructure investments.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
6.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: the PRC’s sustainable development and 
regional  cooperation  promoted.  The  TA  will  have  the  following  outcome:  responsible  and 
sustainable financing in ASEAN (inclusive of GMS), CAREC, and the PRC, improved. The TA will 
have four key outputs.  
  
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
7.  Output 1: Strategy, policy, and technical advice on responsible and sustainable 
financing in the People’s Republic of China provided. The TA will develop a strategic 
framework for responsible and sustainable financing to support the transformation of PRC’s 
 
6  The PRI is a voluntary and aspirational set of investment principles that offers a menu of possible actions for  
incorporating ESG issues into investment practice. 
7  The Equator Principles are a framework adopted by financial institutions for determining, assessing, and managing 
environmental and social risks in project financing.  
8  The GRI standards are the first global standards for sustainability reporting. They represent the global best practice 
for reporting on a range of economic, environmental, and social impacts.

3 
financial sector over the next CPS cycle (2021–2025). This framework will (i) expand and deepen 
the existing green finance policy and standards, such as to consolidate and align the national and 
international taxonomies; (ii) promote international sustainable financing standards (e.g., PRI, 
ESG, Equator Principles, and GRI) in domestic financial institutions; and (iii) develop an advanced 
green finance information technology (IT) system that could facilitate the financial institutions’ 
adoption of international and national green finance taxonomies and other standards, including 
ESG, regulatory reporting, and/or disclosure and public monitoring mechanism.   
 
8.  Output  2:  Sustainable  financial  sector  regulation  and  supervision  systems 
strengthened. The TA will support several new initiatives. The China Banking and Insurance 
Regulatory Commission (CBIRC), which regulates the country’s financial institutions, and the 
China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC), a capital markets regulator, are working to 
introduce new sustainable finance standards. The TA will support the China Institute of Finance 
and Capital Markets (CIFCM), the CSRC’s research and policy advice arm, to establish an ESG 
information disclosure standard for publicly listed companies on the PRC equity markets (e.g., 
through an index system of environment-related information). The TA will help reduce the 
information asymmetries between the investors and the markets and will enable them to better 
assess ESG compliance risks and price the securities accordingly. The CBIRC is undertaking a 
similar initiative for ESG disclosure by commercial banks. In addition, the insurance sector does 
not  have  internationally  aligned  insurance  solvency  regulatory  equivalence  assessment 
standards, such as the Insurance Core Principles9 and the risk-based capital mechanism.10 The 
TA will conduct a comparative study on international insurance solvency regulatory equivalence 
assessment rules and develop a robust solvency regulatory equivalence assessment system for 
the PRC. This will improve the regulation and supervision of the financial markets by introducing 
international best practices and strengthening the technical capacity of the regulators. Thus, the 
PRC’s financial institutions will become better equipped to drive its responsible and sustainable 
financing agenda over the coming years. 
 
9.  Output  3:  Innovative  financial  products  developed.  To  expand  the  concept  of 
sustainable financing, the TA will help commercial banks and other financial institutions in the 
PRC scale up green and blue finance. The TA will assist financial institutions in the PRC’s green 
finance pilot zones and other priority areas in developing innovative green finance products to 
increase their lending volumes for responsible and sustainable financing. For blue finance, the 
financial products will improve ocean health by reducing land-based sources of marine pollution, 
such  as  plastics  and  wastewater  and  agricultural  runoff.  To  align  with  the  government’s 
commitment to become carbon neutral by 2060, the TA will explore financial innovations that 
would contribute to the reduction of the coal-based energy consumption. In addition, the TA will 
review and develop innovative inclusive finance and digital finance products to address social and 
economic inequalities. Aging is a severe social and economic challenge in the PRC and the region. 
In the PRC, the number of people over 60 years old is expected to reach more than 400 million 
by 2030, or about one-third of the PRC’s population, and the country will need about 100,000 
elderly communities to house 250 million elderly citizens by 2040.11 Because the PRC currently 
has only 43,000 elderly communities, longevity finance and old age care have emerged as critical 
issues.  This  includes  the  identification  of  innovative  market-based  financial  instruments  to 
strengthen the long-term care systems in the PRC and beyond. In light of the COVID-19 pandemic, 
the TA will promote regional disaster risk management approaches and disaster risk financing 
 
9 The Insurance Core Principles developed by the International Association of Insurance Supervisors provide a globally 
accepted framework of principles, standards, and guidance for the regulation and supervision of the insurance sector. 
10 Risk-based capital is a method of measuring the minimum amount of capital appropriate for a reporting entity to 
support its overall business operations in consideration of its size and risk profile.  
11  ADB. 2020. Innovative Senior Care Industry Finance in the PRC. Consultant’s report. Manila.

4 
solutions, including management of responses to communicable diseases and disasters.12 For 
knowledge  sharing  and  business  development,  ADB  will  coordinate  with  prominent  local 
institutions such as the Research Center for Green Finance of Tsinghua University and the 
International Institute of Green Finance of Central University of Finance and Economics. 
 
10.  Output 4: Support to regional cooperation on responsible and sustainable financing 
enhanced. To generate RPGs and improve RCI, the TA will promote responsible and sustainable 
financing and financial innovations through the ASEAN+3 financial cooperation (including the 
GMS countries) and CAREC platforms. The ABMI (including CGIF and ASEAN+3 Bond Market 
Forum)  established  under  the  ASEAN+3  financial  cooperation  platform  and/or  the  ACMF 
established  by  the  ASEAN  finance  ministers  can  be  enriched  with  expanded  support  for 
sustainable finance.13 The TA will promote the sharing of knowledge and operational experience 
on responsible and sustainable financing through the ABMI and/or ACMF. This will be achieved 
through  national  and  regional  dissemination  products  and  events,  including  publications, 
workshops, and conferences that will be hosted jointly with national and regional government 
agencies, regulatory bodies, financial institutions, green finance institutions, and/or academic 
institutions across the region. The CAREC 2030 strategy also has a financial and economic 
stability pillar.14 The TA’s responsible and sustainable financing work and the related financial 
innovation  can  be  shared  through  the  CAREC  platform,  contributing  to  financial  sector 
sustainability in CAREC countries (para. 5). To provide benefits to countries in the region, the TA 
will support technical advisory work on green bond taxonomy development and green finance IT 
system development; and review, advise, and, if feasible, facilitate investments in pilot projects 
such as in waste-to-energy. These will generate RPGs throughout the ASEAN+3 (inclusive of 
GMS) and CAREC countries. Beyond knowledge sharing, the TA’s benefits will include promotion 
of international best practices, capital market development, green technologies transfer, and 
improved  project-level  trade  and  investment.  Through  coordination  with  ADB’s  Economic 
Research and Regional Cooperation Department and Southeast Asia Department, as well as 
other relevant departments, the TA will complement ADB efforts. For example, the TA will 
coordinate on the development of local currency green bonds, bond taxonomies, certification 
process, and disclosure by learning from the PRC’s experiences.15 The TA will also collaborate 
with the ADB work on creating ecosystems for green local currency bonds for sustainable 
infrastructure development in ASEAN+3.16 The TA will promote ocean financing by aligning with 
the ocean health and marine economy initiative proposed under ADB’s $5 billion Healthy Oceans 
Action Plan launched in 2019.17 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.7 million, of which $497,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources), $200,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Financial Sector Development Partnership Special Fund,18 and 
$803,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund.19

approach.

to advance the global initiative.

Local Currency Bonds for Infrastructure Development in ASEAN+3. Manila.

The  government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  office 
accommodation, office supplies, secretarial assistance, domestic transportation, and other in-kind 
contributions. The key expenditure items are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  ADB will administer the TA. The Public Management, Financial Sector, and Regional 
Cooperation Division of East Asia Department will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants 
and monitor quality of their work. The implementing agencies will be CBIRC and CIFCM for their 
respective components (output 2). ADB will use k-Nexus, a database of completed and planned 
knowledge products and services by all ADB departments, to avoid duplicating efforts with the 
knowledge product and services under this TA. Consultant recruitments will be optimized with 
internal ADB resources. ADB will prepare a monitoring and evaluation plan. The implementation 
arrangements are summarized in the table.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
14.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis to 
the People’s Republic of China for Supporting Sustainable Finance and Regional Cooperation, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Strategy, policy, and technical advice on responsible and sustainable financing in the PRC 
provided 
1.1 Review and assess responsible and sustainable finance policy and framework in the PRC’s 
financial sector and develop a comprehensive financial sector assessment by consulting PRC’s 
financial institutions, central bank, regulators, and green finance institutions on expanding 
sustainable finance initiatives (from 2021 to 2022) 
1.2 Work with the PRC green finance institutes, such as Research Center for Green Finance of 
Tsinghua University and International Institute of Green Finance of Central University of Finance 
and Economics, to develop comprehensive green finance infrastructure and support mechanism, 
such as central bank supervisory incentive structure (from 2021 to 2023) 
1.3 Provide technical advisory support on the development and implementation of a comprehensive 
green finance IT system for at least 1 commercial bank that incorporate identified sustainable 
finance features—e.g., national and international green finance taxonomies, PRI and ESG 
principles, and disclosure requirements (from 2021 to 2025)  
2.  Sustainable financial sector regulation and supervision systems strengthened  
2.1 Conduct a thorough analysis under CIFCM’s green and sustainable investment and finance 
initiative on challenges hindering the development of sustainable finance, such as environmental 
information asymmetry in the PRC equity markets (from 2021 to 2022)  
2.2 Prepare a comprehensive report for supporting the construction a green and sustainable 
investment and finance index system for the disclosure of corporate environmental information and 
submit it to CIFCM management for review (from 2021 to 2024) 
2.3 Conduct a comparative study between the PRC domestic practices and international best practices 
on solvency regulatory equivalence assessment rules (from 2021 to 2022)

3.5 Assess local market conditions and develop longevity finance product(s) and explore bankable 
longevity finance pipeline projects (from 2021 to 2023)
